titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of the collection at Syracuse University
titlestmt.author: DRC, MW

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: Personal papers of the missionary, adult educator, and literacy pioneer; also contains organizational records of Laubach Literacy, Inc. Collection includes correspondence, administrative papers, financial papers, U.S. and international projects, writings, photographs, and miscellanea.
did.langmaterial:
Majority in
English, literacy manuals in dozens of other languages.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Frank C. Laubach (1884-1970) was a Christian Evangelical missionary, author, and educator who specialized in international literacy. Dr. Laubach recognized literacy as a "first step toward ending the suffering and exploitation of the world's disadvantaged" (Laubach Literacy International brochure); he was the founder of the "Each One Teach One" literacy teaching method and of Laubach Literacy, and is credited with teaching more than 100 million people to read."

Frank Charles Laubach was born in Benton, Pennsylvania on September 2, 1884. He studied at Bloomsburg State College (1901), Perkiomen Prep School (1905), Princeton University (BA, 1909), and Union Theological Seminary (1913). He was married to Effa Seely on May 15, 1912, and earned his MA (1912) and PhD (1915) from Columbia University.

In 1915, Dr. Laubach and his wife went to the Philippines as Congregational missionaries with the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. He was a minister at Cagayan, and taught at Union Theological Seminary in Manila. In 1930, he began literacy work on the island of Mindanao and developed an alphabet for the Maranaws in their own Maranaw language. This was the start of his "Each One Teach One" concept, which encouraged adults taught by the system to then volunteer their time to teach others. From 1930 to 1970, Dr. Laubach traveled to more than one hundred countries developing literacy primers in 312 languages. He and his literacy teams worked with missions, private agencies, governments, U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), the Peace Corps, and UNESCO.

In 1935 Dr. Laubach organized the World Literacy Committee, and in 1941 he became one of the founders of the Committee on World Literacy and Christian Literature, known as "Lit-Lit" (later Intermedia) of the National Council of Churches. He worked with this organization until his retirement in 1954 at the age of 70. In 1951, to facilitate cooperation with government and secular organizations, Dr. Laubach started World Literacy, Inc. (now World Education). In 1955, the year after his retirement, he founded Laubach Literacy, Inc., a non-profit literacy organization with headquarters in Syracuse, New York. His son, Robert, took over the presidency of LLI after Dr. Laubach's death on June 11, 1970. Mrs. Effa Laubach died on March 29, 1973, at the age of 85; the couple are buried in the family plot in Benton, Pennsylvania.

Dr. Laubach was a prolific writer whose books covered a variety of interests, including the Philippines, prayer and spiritual life, challenges to world literacy and to international technical assistance, and materials to teach adults to read (including literacy primers in 312 languages). He gave the impetus to the opening of literacy and journalism courses at Hartford School of Missions, Syracuse University, Asbury College, Baylor University, University of California, and more than twenty other centers across the United States.

Laubach has been recognized many times for his accomplishments. He received honorary degrees from Princeton, Columbia, Syracuse, and Temple Universities, and from Lafayette, Wooster, Muskingam, Marietta, Findlay, and Baldwin-Wallace Colleges.
Time magazine referred to him as the founder of a world-wide literacy drive. Norman Vincent Peale, in
Look, called Laubach one of the five greatest men in the world, and
Newsweek featured him as "one of the grand men of the missionary world." Lowell Thomas called him "the foremost teacher of our times." On the 100th anniversary of his birth, the United States Postal Service honored Dr. Laubach with the issue of a commemorative stamp in the "Great Americans" series.

Four books have been written about him:
Apostle to the Illiterates, by David E. Mason;
Each One Teach One, by Marjorie Medary;
Champion of the Silent Billion, by Helen M. Roberts; and
Frank C. Laubach, Teacher of Millions, by David E. Mason. His work has been taught to Sunday School children in the curriculum of the Methodist, Lutheran, and other denominations. Dozens of religious and secular magazines including
Together,
The Lutheran Standard,
Christian Herald,
Time,
Look,
Newsweek,
Reader's Digest,
Collier's, and
Saturday Evening Post have run articles about "Mr. Literacy."

For a detailed history of Laubach Literacy and related organizations, including the National Affilication for Literacy Advance (NALA), Laubach Literacy Action (LLA), New Readers Press (NRP), and ProLiteracy Worldwide, please refer to the
Laubach Literacy, Inc. Records finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p:
The
Frank C. Laubach Collection contains both the organizational papers of Laubach Literacy, Inc. (LLI) and the personal papers of Frank C. Laubach. The collection traces the development of literacy teaching from the early 1920's, at the beginning of Dr. Laubach's missionary career with the Moro tribe in the Philippines, and reaches into the present efforts of Laubach Literacy, Inc., to deal with illiteracy on a worldwide scale. As such, it is a valuable research tool for students of literacy in America or of world literacy.

The collection includes correspondence, personal papers of both Frank and Effa Laubach, administrative papers, financial papers, writings (manuscripts and articles), organizational and meeting material, and photographs, as well as material relating to trustees, domestic and international projects, languages, and some miscellany.

Correspondence, the first major group of the Laubach Collection, is divided into four subgroups: Frank Laubach, General, Foreign, and Specific files. Dr. Laubach's own correspondence dates are considerably earlier than the other sub-groups.
General correspondence contains organizational correspondence of a varied nature, covering the broad range of questions concerning Laubach Literacy, Inc.
Foreign correspondence pertains to foreign correspondence of such a general nature that it has no specific file.
Specific files contains the correspondence of specific individuals and projects.

The next series,
Frank C. Laubach papers, consist of a great variety of material accumulated over Dr. Laubach's lifetime: biographical material; essays, articles and speeches; scrapbooks and diaries, manuscripts dated before 1955. The notes, memorabilia and data collected during Dr. Laubach's missionary career in the Philippines are of particular philosophical and historical interest.

The papers of Laubach's wife,
Effa Seely Laubach (1882-1973), consist of a small amount of correspondence and miscellaneous notes.
Trustees' material consists of agenda, meetings, minutes of meetings and decisions concerning the Board of Trustees of Laubach Literacy, Inc.

Administrative files are divided into two subgroups. Administrative papers consists of major materials regarding organizational policy, contracts and personnel information. Administrative correspondence is all interoffice memoranda within and from Laubach Literacy, Inc.
Financial papers include budgets, auditors' reports, bank statements and corporate assessments.

Projects, domestic consist of literacy programs, projects, and training workshops sponsored by Laubach Literacy in the United States. Included here is National Affiliation for Literacy Advance (NALA) material as well as the papers and records of state and local literacy organizations.

Projects, overseas contains material related to literacy projects abroad, such as U.S. Government (AID, Peace Corps) contracts, proposals, and support; and monthly reports from Laubach staff members located in other countries.
Languages contain all the primers and reading materials developed or used by Laubach in any language. More than 300 languages are represented.

Manuscripts and articles contain the manuscripts developed at Laubach Literacy, Inc., from 1955 to 1969. This group also holds other manuscripts and articles prepared by Laubach staff members or interested persons.
Organizations and meetings contains the records and papers of organizations, conferences and meetings not directly sponsored by Laubach Literacy, but of interest to Laubach staff members or Trustees.
Miscellaneous holds over six boxes of newspaper clippings collected at Laubach Literacy, and also includes unclassified newsletters and pamphlets.
Photographs relate to a variety of Laubach projects, both domestic and overseas, and are filed by geographical location. Also included are photographs of the Laubach family.

The collection closes with 99
Streamlined Reading films covering lessons in literacy instruction.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The subdivisions of Correspondence are arranged chronologically except for Specific files, which are alphabetical by name. All remaining series are arranged alphabetically by name, title, or topic as appropriate.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
See also the
Laubach Literacy International Records. In addition, the library has many published works by Frank Laubach; please refer to &summitref; for a complete listing.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Majority gift of Frank C. Laubach, 1966-1978.
Material in boxes 328A, 328B and 328C, gift of David Mason, 2011.

scopecontent.p: Introduce books; welcome by Dr. Laubach; learn letters A-L; practice writing in simple words and sentences.
Lesson 3; introduce R, S, T, V, W, Y; use them in words and sentences, then write words.
Review charts #2 and #3; practice writing letters in book.
Introduce Z, A, E, I, 0, U; use in words and sentences; demonstrate how to write these letters, and write words using them.
Using Lesson 2 in book, y endings on words are explored; then these endings are used in sentences which are written in workbook.
Importance of sounds in word building; putting basic sounds together to form words.
Miss Helen Brown uses the Laubach method to review vowel sounds and then inserts them in monosyllabic words.
Review of Lessons 1-3; fill in blanks in sentences using words from lists and story.
Miss Helen Brown practices writing sentences using word groups "This is a ," insert simple adjectives and adverbs.
Miss Helen Brown reviews vowel sounds; then spells words the way they sound; and then spells them properly and uses them in sentences. For use with blue book.
Sentences, questions; practice reading in rhythm, natural breaks; practices writing T, P, N, H, K, W, S, F, R, B, L
Manuscript and cursive writing; practice writing to music; small b, f, t, r, y, p, d, h, n, v, g, j
Review of Lesson 3; Chart 4; sounds of Z and vowels; practice.
Practice writing capital letters to music; J, K, L, M, N, P, R, S, T, V, W, Y.
Reading and writing practice from Chart 2 and Chart 3; the sounds Sh, J, K, M, N; Chart 3, R, S, etc., to end of alphabet.
Writing practice from Chart 2; introduce last part of alphabet.
Chart 5, end of Book 1; last two letters, x and q; the sounds sh, th, ch, and wh.
Review Chart 1; practice writing letters A-L.
Review of sounds in Charts 1 and 2; practice writing letters in Chart 2; capitals and small letters B through P.
Review consonants B through H; practice writing consonants; some pictures; only one demonstration showing how to write small letters and capital letters.
Review Chart 1; introduce Chart 2; practice writing the letters.
Practice writing letters to music.
Practice writing letters using guidelines.
Reading in Book 2; Lesson 1; sound of i.
Practice with z and combinations qu, th, and wh; review sentences; questions, who, where; reading the alphabet; saying and writing alphabet.
Writing X and Q to music; writing numbers 2, 3, 4, 5; sentences written about pictures shown.
Practice writing words by sound; top, tag, ted, bat, bob, big, leg, lap, lug, pig, pod.
Lesson 1 in Streamlined English; combining consonant sounds with i.
Practice writing words containing tall and short letters.
Practice writing small and capital letters B through Z and vowels; practice writing sounds th, sh, ch, wh, qu.
Review of Lessons 4 and 5; Chart 4, Z and vowels; Chart 5, x, qu, th, sh, ch, wh; Story 5, review of writing.
Chart 2, practice sounds J through Y; practice writing.
Review of Book 2; u; Lesson 1, 2, and 3.
Lesson 19, new sound, ou, ow; pictures; practice reading; practice writing.
Continue use of vowel A; practice reading apple sound of A; practice writing.
Lesson 5, vowel sound A as in apple; practice reading; practice writing.
Lesson 4, letter E; review words with 'bed' sound of E; practice reading; sentence patterns; practice writing.
Review homework Lesson 5; Lesson 6; helping words; practice writing; practice saying first 15 letters of alphabet.
Review of AR sound; practice reading, practice writing.
Review of Lessons 4, 5, and 6; practice writing sounds TH, I, S.
Review lesson of capital and small letters; writing to music; how to sit and hold pencil; one demonstration writing letters A through R.
Writing and spelling; looking at pictures and writing a sentence about each picture.
Story of Dr. John; Lesson 8; the orange sound of the letter 0; pictures used for demonstration; practice reading; practice writing.
Review of sounds A as in apple and R; sound of both letters together; pictures used to demonstrate lesson; practice reading The Farm and The Farmer; contractions; practice writing.
Review of vowel sounds; pictures used to demonstrate short vowel sounds; practice writing; Y as a vowel; no pictures.
Words containing the sound A as in apple; practice writing.
Review of vowel sound E as in egg; pictures used to demonstrate sound; practice reading; practice writing numbers 6, 7, 8 and 9.
Practice writing to learn to spell; pictures used often; practice with ell and ill combinations.
Lesson 6, commonly used words; parts of words; pass, ask, ance; pictures used throughout; ast, ath; practice reading; practice writing.
Practice writing last eight letters of alphabet, small and capitals, with music; numbers 1 through 9; practicing reciting ,alphabet through R; no pictures.
Story of Dr. John; Lesson 9; New sound of UR, ER, and IR; practice with sound of R; practice reading and writing with new sound; pictures used to demonstrate sound.
Review of vowel sounds A as in apple, E as in egg, I as in in, O as in orange, and U as in up; Y sometimes as in city; practice reading and writing; pictures used to demonstrate; little repetition.

Recitation of alphabet; how to find names in a telephone directory; abbreviations; Mr., Mrs., and others; practice using the telephone; telephone dial used as demonstration tool; no pictures; emergency numbers.
Review of Lessons 8 and 9; sounds of o as in orange; U as in up, Y as in city; numbers, no pictures.
The long vowel sound of the letter E; , ee, ea, ey, e-e; different ways E may be written; pictures used; practice reading; practice writing.
Begin study of long vowel sounds; , ai, ay, a(k)e or a(m)e; different ways A may be written as a long vowel; pictures used; practice reading; practice writing.
Practice writing and spelling; use of new sound; er=ur, er, ir; letters rest on bottom line of writing; special letters go below bottom line.
Vowel sound of the letter O; five ways of writing long O, o, o-e, oe, cw, oa; practice reading; pictures used; practice writing.
Vowel sound of long I; Lesson 12; four ways to write the sound I, ide-ive-ine, igh, CI; practice reading; pictures used; practice writing.
Review of long vowel sounds; no pictures; sounds of A, I, E; dictation of sentences using those sounds; practice reading and writing.
Continuation of review of long vowel sounds of I, A, E; sentences dictated; no pictures.
Completion of Lesson 12; practice reading sentences with long sounds of I; review of long vowel sounds of A, E, and I; practice writing; no pictures.

Reading, groups of words; dictation of sentences to practice reading by groups; practice writing; Lesson 13; Long vowel sounds of O; , o-e, oe, ow, oa; practice writing words with long o vowel sound; no pictures.
Lesson 14; story about farm life; study of sound of OR; practice reading, practice writing; pictures.
Review of homework of Lessons 10 and 11; dictation and writing of words having long vowel sound E; no pictures.
Lesson 17; sounds of diphthong AU, AW, ought, aught, alk; story with pictures; practice reading; practice writing.
Review of Lessons 13, 14, and 15; read sentences; Lesson 16; future tense; definitions of tense and verbs; practice writing; no pictures.
Writing and spelling lesson about a farmer and his house; pictures used; sentences written about pictures; practice reading; practice writing.
Lesson 16; diphthong OO; future tense; pictures used; practice reading; practice writing.
Symbols, letters, pictures, and signs; pictures used; what symbols mean; practice writing words found on signs; color and shape of signs.
Lesson 15; story about a woman cook; sound of U as in put; UU as in cook, woman, good, looking, wood, etc.; pictures used to illustrate story; practice writing new words learned in lesson.
Review of long vowel sounds of 5, u as in put, 5; street signs; practice reading; practice writing; no pictures.
Writing and spelling; dictation, hook, wool, hood, cookie, stood, and woodcarver; practice writing sentences using oo sound; no pictures.
Going over homework sentences of Lesson 16; review using sentences to illustrate three sound alike words, to, two, too; practice reading and writing; dictation; no pictures.
Dictation; words having long u sound; practice reading and writing; no pictures; often used together words, "let us go."
Lesson helping to spell sound au, aw, ought, aught, alk; sentences illustrating these sounds; practice reading and writing; no pictures.
Review sentences of Lesson 17; ai, oo, ar, ee, uu; practice reading and writing; no pictures.
Lesson 18; long vowel sound of E, ue, ew, use, ure; practice reading and writing; dictation story illustrating sound; pictures used.
Review of Lesson 16; homework; Number 17; word list; verbs; helping words; no pictures.

Continuation of Lesson 19; five new words; nouns, vowels, consonants, syllables, accent; practice writing vowels; practice writing consonants; definition of syllables; practice writing syllables; rules about vowel sounds; definition of accent; practice writing accent; no pictures.

More about consonants; unvoiced letters t, p, k, ch, f, s, etc; voiced letters b, d, g, j, v, z; voiced letters through the nose, m, n, ng; silent letters; two ways to pronounce s; rules; exceptions; practice reading and writing; story of three Roberts; no pictures.

Rules governing pronunciation of vowels; diphthongs; practice reading and writing; dictation of sentences having one vowel words and two vowel words; fords for ex. pin and pine, not and note, cap and cape; no pictures.
Lesson 20; new sound of and oy; pictures used to illustrate words having the new sound; story using new sound; practice reading and writing.

How to use dictionary; parts of words; syllables, accents, hyphen; definitions of these words; pen-man-ship, friend-ly; one syllable words; how they are pronounced; practice reading, writing, and pronouncing one or more syllable words; sign indicating short vowel sound, e.g., pen; no pictures.
Review of Lessons 18, 19 and 20; filling in blanks in sentences; practice reading sentences; practice in s sound and of and oy sounds; practice writing sentences using these sounds; exclamation mark.
Review of Lessons 18, 19 and 20; practice reading words from word lists; things; verbs; helping words; nouns; practice reading sentences; practice writing.

Review of long vowel sounds; 5, ay, ai, a/e; baby, play, braid, face; e, e-e, ee, ea, ey; be, Pete, tree, read, key; i, i-e, igh, y; child, fine, bright, cry; 6, o-e, oe, ow, oa; old, home, pictures; u, ue, ew, u-e; due, news, cure; Y, by; no pictures.

The dictionary; how to use it; entry words; alphabetical order; practice putting words in alphabetical order by their second letter; same by third letter; same by fourth letter; guide words; vocabulary; phonetic spelling, n, noun, meanings of words; pronunciation; no pictures.
Canister 91 Two sounds of g, hard and soft; go, gem; rules governing usage; practice reading and writing sentences with the two sounds of g; no pictures.

Help in word recognition; explanation pronouncing ch; three ways to pronounce ch; ch as pronounced in child and such; exception is stomach; tch is always soft as in catch or kitchen; beginning ch sound three ways; child, Christmas, chef; rules governing sounds of ch; before a vowel, when in middle of a word, names of people with ch in middle; before 1 and r; s before ch; ch = sh in words coming from French.
Th and tion; this thing; voiced and unvoiced; practice with th as beginning sound; tion and sion = shun sound; practice; no pictures.
Short review of voiced and unvoiced letters; quiz; p, unvoiced, z; voiced, ten examples; no pictures; review of silent letters; pronunciations of s.

Rules about sounds of the letter c; when c is before the letters e, i, or y it has soft sound as s in snake; two ways to pronounce c; soft as soft s and hard as in k; when c is before any letter except above letters it has hard sound; ch as sh; practice in dictation; no pictures.

Sounds of ng; three rules; as in king and ring; voiced through nose; practice pronouncing examples ng in the middle of a word as in finger, angry and other examples; practice; exceptions to the rules; long, longer, longest; strong and young, etc. nge is pronounced like nje; change, danger, edge, strange, etc.; practice; no pictures.
Questions about three stories; study of word lists; new words learned; practice reading, writing, spelling; no pictures.

The last lesson; 22 new words which break rules; pronunciation; believe, busy, business, heaven, leather, opposite, pearl, tongue, pleasant, building, island, creased, relief, religion, rough, cough, sew, spread, sword, thread, carriage, youth; all these words break a rule; words with unnecessary a, earth, heaven, pearl, dean, instead, etc.; pronunciation of ough; five ways, though, rough, cough, plough, through; no pictures.

Rules how consonants can change sounds of vowels; ong, awng; long, belong, strong, etc.; all, awl; all words that come from all are spelled al, already, almost, etc., except shall; war and wal, a, aw, war, wall, etc.; double consonants following vowels give vowel short sound; manner, etc.; dividing words with double consonants into syllables; practice writing; silent letters; w before r and k and g silent in front of n; silent letters in front of t; o in front of us; 1 in front of k; no pictures.
